r:Title.r:String: National Survey of Health and Development

r:PublisherName.r:String: MRC Unit for Lifelong Health and Ageing, UCL

r:Copyright.r:String: Copyright MRC Unit for Lifelong Health and Ageing, UCL. All rights reserved.

r:Abstract.r:Content: The Medical Research Council (MRC) National Survey of Health and Development (NSHD) is the oldest and longest running of the British birth cohort studies. Also known as the 1946 British birth cohort study, it has followed 5,362 men and women since their birth in England, Scotland or Wales in one week in March 1946, so far until age 70 years. Today, with study members entering their seventies , the NSHD offers a unique opportunity to explore the long-term biological and social processes of ageing and how ageing is affected by factors acting across the whole of life. From an initial maternity survey of 13,687 of all births recorded in England, Scotland and Wales during one week of March, 1946, a socially stratified sample of 5,362 singleton babies born to married parents was selected for follow-up. This sample comprises the NSHD cohort and participants have been studied 25 times. During their childhood, the main aim of the NSHD was to investigate how the environment at home and at school affected physical and mental development and educational attainment. During adulthood, the main aim was to investigate how childhood health and development and lifetime social circumstances affected their adult health and function and how these change with age. NSHD is now a life course study of ageing. Study members were asked to attend a clinic at age 60-64 for a range of assessments (or alternatively have a home visit). They were invited for a further home visit at 69 years , updating information on health, lifestyle and life circumstances as well as obtaining repeat physical and cognitive measurements. Postal questionnaires were completed before the clinic and home visits. A subset of 500 study members are also being invited to participate in a Neuroscience sub-study. Study website: http://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: The MRC is responsible for co-coordinating and funding medical research in the UK. It is part of UK Research and Innovation (UKRI) which is a non-departmental public body (NDPB) funded by the UK government (Medical Research Council (United Kingdom), n.d. ).
13,687 births recorded in England, Scotland and Wales during March 1946

r:Abstract.r:Content: The initial maternity survey was based on all births in England, Scotland and Wales in a single week of 1946. Covering 13,687 cases it looked antenatal (the mother and her work, antenatal care, diet whilst pregnant, maternity benefits, the cost of pregnancy) and postnatal arrangements (how the baby was cared for, the period of confinement and the end of that time, help given around the house and with the care of children). It also collected data on household composition and the occupation of the father. Of these, 5,362 cases continued into the National Survey for Health and Development. These cases are those for whom there is data available within the NSHD. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Collecting and assembling data from multiple, often heterogeneous sources that have one or more reference points in common, and at least one of the sources was originally produced for other purposes.
The PIC, is a UK social research group founded in 1936. It has been housed at the London School of Economics since 1945 (Population Investigation Committee, n.d.).
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Collecting and assembling data from multiple, often heterogeneous sources that have one or more reference points in common, and at least one of the sources was originally produced for other purposes.

OrganizationName.r:String: Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists

r:Description.r:Content: The RCOG is professional association based in London, UK. Its members, including people with and without medical degrees, work in the field of obstetrics and gynaecology that is, pregnancy, childbirth, and female sexual and reproductive health (Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, n.d.).
All women who delivered during a single week in March 1946.

r:Abstract.r:Content: In 1947 a sub-sample comprising all 676 'premature' babies (of birth weight 5.5 lbs or less) and a set of controls were contacted. The controls were chosen from the same or nearby Local Health Authority areas and matched for sex, birth order, maternal age, social class and other unspecified social circumstances. In total, 1,362 people were contacted. There were asked questions on the details of the delivery, post-natal care and the health of the baby. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Label.r:Content: 1947 Supplementary Questionnaire for Inquiry into Prematurity

The LSE(officially the London School of Economics and Political Science) is a public research university located in London, UK, and a member institution of the federal University of London (London School of Economics, n.d.).

OrganizationName.r:String: Institute of Child Health, University of London

r:Description.r:Content: The ICH was founded in 1946 by professor Alan Moncrieff with the funding of a chair in child health by the Nuffield Foundation. It acted as a postgraduate school of preventive and therapeutic paediatrics of Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children and the University of London. This is now called as UCL Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health (UCL Great Ormond Street Institute of Child Health, n.d.).

All 'premature' babies (birth weight 5.5lbs or less) born in a single week in March 1946 and a set of controls from the same or nearby local health authority areas and matched for sex, birth order, maternal age, social class and other unspecified social circumstances

r:Abstract.r:Content: Health visitors collected information from health records and interviewed mothers at home about the health, home and family circumstances of the mother and baby. They made assessments of maternal care and home circumstances. Topics covered include: development of the baby, domestic accidents, infectious diseases, immunisation, miscellaneous illnesses, immunisation, feeding, infant welfare, baby's sleeping arrangements, use of nurseries and the dwelling and the household. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Collecting and assembling data from multiple, often heterogeneous sources that have one or more reference points in common, and at least one of the sources was originally produced for other purposes.
A sample of the original infants.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Health visitors collected information from health records and interviewed mothers at home. They also made assessments of maternal care and home circumstances. Maternal reports of hospital admissions were checked with the hospital records. Topics covered include: accidents, illnesses, circumcision, in patient treatment, sleeping arrangements, habits, welfare centres, nurseries, the mother and what help she received, the husband's occupation and the household. Anthropometry measures were also taken. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Collecting and assembling data from multiple, often heterogeneous sources that have one or more reference points in common, and at least one of the sources was originally produced for other purposes.
All eligible study members.

r:Abstract.r:Content: School nurses and health visitors interviewed mothers at home and school doctors undertook a medical examination of the child. Maternal reports of hospital admissions were also checked with hospital records. Topics covered included: accidents, illnesses, hospital admissions, bladder and bowel training, habits, sleep and play, the dwelling, the household, the mother's work, subsequent pregnancies, separation from the mother, education of the father and mother, and the occupation of the present husband. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

OrganizationName.r:String: The Society of Medical Officers of Health

r:Description.r:Content: The Society of Medical Officers of Health was previously the English society of metropolitan Medical Officer for Health which was established in 1869. The Society of Medical Officers of Health became the Society of Medical Officers of Health in 1873 then the Society of Public Health in 1989 which merged with the Royal Institute of Public Health to form the Royal Society for Public Health in 2008 (Royal Institute of Public Health, n.d.).

r:Abstract.r:Content: School doctors undertook the medical examination and health visitors and school nurses completed records of school absences, accidents and the form about the school and preschool preparation of the study child for school. Topics covered included: accidents, maternal reports of hospital admissions, bedwetting, type of school and class, the child's age at their first reading instruction and parental interest in school progress. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: School nurses and health visitors interviewed mothers at home about the child's health and development, school absences, play, the mother's work and the home and family circumstances. Teachers administered cognitive tests at school. Topics covered included: accidents, illnesses, hospital admissions and out-patient visits, school clinic visits, absences, bed wetting, general health and behaviour, schooling, play and hobbies, the dwelling, the household, the mother's work, subsequent pregnancies and family history. Tests included a sentence reading test, a mechanical reading and comprehension test and a picture intelligence test. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.

The NFER was founded in 1946 as a centre for educational research and development in England and Wales. The foundation's work includes educational research, evaluation of education and training programmes, and the development of assessments and specialist information services (National Foundation for Educational Research, n.d.).

r:Abstract.r:Content: School nurses and health visitors interviewed mothers at home about the child's health, development and behaviour, school absences, play, the mother's work and the home and family circumstances; they also commented on the state of the dwelling. Topics covered included: accidents, illnesses, hospital admissions and out-patient visits, school clinic visits, absences, bed wetting, general health and behaviour, the mother's work and schooling. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: The cohort member's teacher and the school's head teacher completed the postal questionnaire about the type of school, the child's attainment and behaviour, and parental interest. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
The schools of all eligible study members.

r:Abstract.r:Content: School nurses and health visitors interviewed mothers at home about the child's health, school absence, interests and behaviour, and the home and family circumstances. They also assessed the state of the dwelling. School doctors undertook the medical examination and teachers complete the questionnaire about the school and administered the cognitive tests at school. Topics included: accidents, illnesses, hospital admissions and out-patient visits, school clinic visits, absences, schooling, hobbies and outside interests, general health and behaviour, domestic help, occupation of present husband, subsequent pregnancies, the mother's work and the household and dwelling. The tests included the General Ability Test, a Mechanical Reading and Word Comprehension test, an Arithmetic test and a Handwriting test. At this age a control sample of a third of single births excluded by the original sampling criteria and who had fathers in manual employment (approximately 2,000 cases) were given the same medical examination as the cohort members. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: 4,127 teachers of cohort members responded to a postal questionnaire assessing the child's attainment, attitude to school work, behaviour and habits, and gave information on school absence. Cohort members completed a postal questionnaire about aspirations and interests, the questions of which comprised the Pintner Personality Inventory. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: School nurses and health visitors interviewed mothers at home about the cohort child's health, schooling and employment, and their own and their husband's health, and their home and family circumstances, and health visitors and school nurses also assessed the state of the dwelling. Teachers completed a postal questionnaire about the cohort child's absences, attitude to school work, behaviour, habits and preparations for school leaving. Teachers also administered at school the questions to the cohort child about preparation for school leaving (printed at the front of the cognitive test booklet) and the cognitive tests. Head-teachers completed the postal questionnaire about the school and its amenities and services for career guidance, and about the school's socioeconomic profile. School doctors carried out the medical examination. Hospitals to which cohort member children had been admitted were asked to complete a postal questionnaire about health, length of admission, visiting arrangements, diagnosis, treatment and discharge. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

OrganizationName.r:String: Scottish Council for Research in Education

r:Description.r:Content: The SCRE was set up by the Scottish teachers’ union (The Educational Institute of Scotland, EIS) and the Association of Directors of Education in 1928 (Scottish Council for Research in Education, n.d.).

r:PublisherName.r:String: MRC Unit, London School of Economics

r:Abstract.r:Content: Cohort members who were still at school completed the postal questionnaire about intentions for further education and work, and on leisure interests and health, and the short version of the Maudsley Personality Inventory (Eysenck H.J. 1958 Journal of Applied Psychology 42, 14-17). Teachers completed the postal questionnaire about the school for those who had not yet left, and the cohort member's examinations, absences, and temperament. Local Education Authorities were asked in a postal questionnaire about whether the cohort member was still at school. Cohort members who had become students in further or higher education, for example in post-school colleges or universities, were asked to complete a postal questionnaire about the university or college, preparation for work, holidays and leisure interests and health, and the short Maudsley Personality Inventory. Administrative authorities at colleges were asked to complete a postal questionnaire about examinations taken by the cohort member, and about health and temperament. Cohort members who were no longer continuing in formal education were asked if they would consent to be interviewed by the local Youth Employment Officer about work, training and health; they were also asked at that interview to complete questions about work. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Collecting and assembling data from multiple, often heterogeneous sources that have one or more reference points in common, and at least one of the sources was originally produced for other purposes.

The MRC Unit now known as the MRC Unit Lifelong Health and Ageing is currently based at the University College London (mrc unit lifelong health ageing ucl, n.d.). It was previously based at the London School of Economics. The unit is home of the National Survey of Health and Development and other population-based studies. It's mission is to identify social and biological factors that affect lifelong health, ageing and the development of chronic disease risk by: using and enhancing the NSHD and other population-based studies; and exchanging knowledge gained with policymakers, health practitioners and other research users, and promoting public understanding of healthy ageing (MRC units, n.d.)

r:Abstract.r:Content: Postal questionnaires were sent to school or college attended to ask administrators about courses taken by cohort members. For cohort members who were no longer in education, postal questionnaires were sent to Youth Employment Service officers to complete from records or other sources about vocational guidance given and training and other courses attended. Members of the control study population were sent postal questionnaires about employment and courses attended. The control sample comprised a third of single births excluded by the initial sampling procedure, and all with fathers in manual employment (N=approx 2000). Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

Cohort members who were at university were asked to complete a postal questionnaire about their courses, leisure activities, and health, and were asked also to complete the short Maudsley Personality Inventory. r:Abstract.r:Content: For cohort members who were at school, college or in further or technical education the administrative authorities of those establishments were asked to complete postal questionnaires about courses attended. A separate postal questionnaire was sent to university and college students about courses attended, leisure time activities, and health, including the short Maudsley Personality Inventory. Health visitors were asked to make home visits to all cohort members to ask questions about health and employment, and a postal version for self-completion was sent to those who did not wish to be interviewed or who could not be contacted by a health visitor. In addition cohort members who were at university in 1965 were interviewed by study team members using a semi-structured method without a questionnaire to ask about their school preparation for university, their choice of university subject, specialisation at university, views on the so-called 'two cultures' (i.e. arts and sciences) debate, accommodation, and comments on the perceived function of a university. 299 students were invited and 193 took part. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Abstract.r:Content: A postal questionnaire was sent to all cohort members to ask about marriage, fertility, health, smoking, employment, training and further education and earnings. Health visitors attempted contacts and data collections with non-respondents. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Data collection was contracted to Social and Community Planning Research whose interviewers requested home visits with all cohort members resident in England, Wales and Scotland. Questionnaires were used to ask about the family in this household and the wider family, and cohort members' own health, training, employment and skills, earnings, social participation, and social imagery questionnaires. Cohort members were also asked to complete a verbal ability test and the short Maudsley Personality Inventory. Short versions of the questionnaires were sent to those reluctant or unwilling to give enough time for the whole set of questionnaires. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
The Social and Community Planning Research was founded in London, UK in 1969 and later became the National Centre for Social Research (National Centre for Social Research, n.d.).

r:Abstract.r:Content: The H6 postal questionnaire was sent to all cohort members to ask about the family, health, employment, smoking, and sports participation and fitness. Two physicians used a dietary and health questionnaire at home visits to 172 of 238 cohort members invited to take part in a study of the effect of breast feeding, and who had been selected on that basis: see Marmot MG et al 1980 Journal of Epidemiology & Community Health, vol. 34, pp 164-167 for further information. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Data collection was carried out at home visits to cohort members by research nurses recruited by the study team. Questionnaires were used to ask about family and home circumstances, health, employment and social participation, experience of disturbing life events, smoking habits and diet. The nurses made a number of body measurements, measured pulse rate, blood pressure, respiratory function, and used the short Present State Examination, a clinically validated questionnaire that evaluated mental health. Nurses explained how to use the diet diary, and asked cohort members to post them back at the end of 5 consecutive days of completion. Cohort members self-completed questionnaires about leisure time exercise and returned them to the nurse. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Assessing specific properties (or characteristics) of beings, things, phenomena by applying pre-established standards and/or specialized instruments or techniques.
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Data collection was carried out at home visits to cohort members by research nurses recruited by the study team. Questionnaires were used to ask about family and home circumstances, health, employment, earnings, and social participation, experience of disturbing life events, hearing, smoking and exercise habits, and diet. Nurses used the Psychiatric Symptom Frequency inventory to ask about mental health. Nurses made a number of body measurements, measured pulse rate, blood pressure, and respiratory function. Cohort members were asked to self-complete in the course of the visit questionnaires about disability, work characteristics, and recall of relationships with parents (the Parental Bonding questionnaire). Nurses administered a visual search test, a verbal memory test, and the CAGE questions on alcohol habits. Nurses completed diet diary entries for the 2 previous days by asking the cohort member to recall all the details, in order to demonstrate the kind of detail required, and to bring away from the home visit diet diary data. The nurse left a copy of those completed diary entries with the cohort member, and asked her/him to completed the diary for the rest of the day of the interview and 4 subsequent days, before returning it by post. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered writing and diaries to capture narratives, stories, diaries and written texts created and collected on paper.
Face-to-face paper and pencil interviewing.

r:Title.r:String: 1993 Women's Health in the Middle Years Sub-Study (Age 47)

r:Abstract.r:Content: The target sample was 1,788 women cohort members. Postal questionnaires were sent out at ages 47, 48, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53, and 54 years, and a total of 1,572 women gave information on at least one of these occasions. Non-responders to the postal questionnaire who were interviewed at the home visit in 1999 completed a short questionnaire about menopause and hysterectomy that matched questions asked on the postal questionnaires. A further follow-up study took place at 57 years (N=1,387). In all, 1735 women provided information on menopause and hysterectomy at one of these occasions. At 59 years those who had reported having a hysterectomy (N=374) were sent a questionnaire. In addition information was collected on confinements of women cohort members. Postal questionnaires were used in each of the contacts with women cohort members. Reports of mammographic examination were checked with hospitals and copies of mammograms obtained. The study of confinements used a postal questionnaire to hospitals. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Label.r:Content: 1993 Women's Health in the Middle Years Postal Questionnaire

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

UCL Medical School is the medical school of University College London and is located in London, UK. The School provides a wide range of undergraduate and postgraduate medical education programmes and also has a medical education research unit and an education consultancy unit (UCL Medical School, n.d.).
All eligible female study members.

r:Title.r:String: 1994 Women's Health in the Middle Years Sub-Study (Age 48)

r:Abstract.r:Content: The target sample was 1,788 women cohort members. Postal questionnaires were sent out at ages 47, 48, 49, 50, 51, 52, 53, and 54 years, and a total of 1,572 women gave information on at least one of these occasions. Non-responders to the postal questionnaire who were interviewed at the home visit in 1999 completed a short questionnaire about menopause and hysterectomy that matched questions asked on the postal questionnaires. A further follow-up study took place at 57 years (N=1,387). In all, 1735 women provided information on menopause and hysterectomy at one of these occasions. At 59 years those who had reported having a hysterectomy (N=374) were sent a questionnaire. In addition information was collected on confinements of women cohort members. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Label.r:Content: 1994 Women's Health in the Middle Years Postal Questionnaire

r:Label.r:Content: 1998 Women's Health in the Middle Years Postal Questionnaire

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Data collection was carried out at home visits to cohort members by research nurses recruited and employed by the National Centre for Social Research. An electronic questionnaire was administered by nurses using laptop computers to ask about home and family circumstances, health, disability, employment, earnings, social participation, smoking and exercise habits, and experience of disturbing life events. Nurses administered tests of lower body strength and balance, and made body measurements, and measured blood pressure, respiratory function, and grip strength, and examined hands and knees for signs of osteoarthritis. They also took a blood sample and a cheek swab from which DNA was derived. Measures were also derived from the non-fasting blood sample of cardiovascular risk factors (cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, triglyceride, glycosolated haemoglobin) and nutritional markers (red cell folate, plasma folate, plasma B12, plasma ferritin). Nurses left a diet diary to be completed over the next 6 days and returned by post. During the course of the home visit the cohort member was asked to complete a short paper questionnaire that included questions about diet and alcohol consumption, hearing and vision, spare-time activities, relationships with others, the short (28 item) General Health Questionnaire including the psychosis screening questions, and questions bladder problems (men only), menopausal symptoms and the use of hormone replacement therapy (women only). In addition a pilot study took place in 2 locations in order to test cohort members' response to invitation to a clinic for data collection. The measures are described in the Clinic Pilot Study form. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered writing and diaries to capture narratives, stories, diaries and written texts created and collected on paper.

r:Description.r:Content: RFUCMS was formed in 1998 from the merger of two medical schools, the Middlesex Hospital and University College Hospital. In 2008, it was renamed UCL Medical School.

r:Abstract.r:Content: A feasibility study on 10% of the NSHD sample living near the Wellcome Trust Clinical Research Facility (CRF) in Manchester took place during 2006-2007. Data from the remaining sample were collected from 2008 to 2010 at CRFs located in Edinburgh, Birmingham, Cardiff and London. The protocol for the 2006-1010 data collection can be found in the published 2011 cohort profile (Cohort Profile: Updating the cohort profile for the MRC National Survey of Health and Development: a new clinic-based data collection for ageing research) and on our public website. Study website: https://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:Abstract.r:Content: A postal questionnaire was sent to all eligible cohort members when they were aged 68 to ask about family, home, work and retirement, health, hospital admissions, wellbeing (WEMWBS), common health-related problems (fractures, falls, pain, incontinence), physical and mental fatigue, lifestyle (smoking, drinking, diet, exercise, and sleep habits), mastery, social activities and networks, religious and spiritual beliefs and personality (Big 5). Up to two reminder letters were sent to those who did not return a completed questionnaire. The postal questionnaire was completed by 2367 study members living in England, Scotland and Wales, representing 84% of the target sample for the postal questionnaire. Study website: http://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:Abstract.r:Content: Data collection was carried out at home visits to cohort members by research nurses recruited and employed by the fieldwork partners Kantar Public and Medicals Direct Group (MDG). An electronic questionnaire (CAPI) was administered by nurses using laptop computers to ask about health, vision, hearing, knee and hand stiffness, medication use, disability, difficulties with daily activities, personal care, alcohol consumption, smoking, exercise, time spent sitting down and whether biological parents are still alive. Nurses also administered tests of lower body strength and balance, and made body measurements, and measured pulse rate, blood pressure, respiratory function and grip strength. They also took a non-fasting blood sample and while the bloods were prepared for centrifuging cohort members were asked to complete a short paper questionnaire that included the short (28 item) General Health Questionnaire including the psychosis screening questions. Nurses also administered the Addenbrooke's Cognitive examination (ACE), visual search task and finger tapping test. At the end of the home visit cohort members were asked if they would like to wear an activity monitor for the following 7 days. Nurses left a short activity questionnaire with the study members who had consented to wear the monitor and this was to be completed and returned by post along with the monitor at the end of the 7 day period. The home visit, including blood sample collection, took place at age 69 for the majority (97%), and at 70 years for the remainder. Study website: http://www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: Country
Face-to-face computer-assisted personal interviewing.

Kantar Public works with clients in government, the public sector, global institutions, NGOs and commercial businesses to advise in the delivery of public policy, public services and public communications.
MDG was founded in 1994 and provides medical data gathering services to the life insurance market, and specialist reports and rehabilitation services to support claims services (MDG, n.d.).
Face-to-face paper-and-pencil interviewing.
Registering by mechanical or electronic means, in a form that allows the information to be retrieved and/or reproduced.
Self-administered questionnaire using a traditional paper questionnaire.

r:PublisherName.r:String: MRC Unit for Lifelong Health and Ageing at UCL

r:Abstract.r:Content: The COVID 19 Survey collects information from participants in 5 national cohort studies about how the Coronavirus epidemic has affected their lives. The data from the survey will help researchers understand the health, social, and economic impacts of the COVID-19 outbreak. It will be especially important for understanding how people at different life stages are being affected, and how prior life experiences shape resilience or vulnerability to its effects.  By following participants’ lives into the future, the studies will be able to track the longer-term consequences of the pandemic too. Study website: www.nshd.mrc.ac.uk/

r:Description.r:Content: England, Scotland and Wales
Computer-assisted web interviewing (CAWI). Data are collected using a web questionnaire, produced with a program for creating web surveys.

Participants from the MRC National Survey of Health and Development. The invitation was initially sent to participates via email to all those for whom an email address was held, including emigrants, but not including those who have permanently withdrawn from the study, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'. A follow-up letter was then sent to all participants whom a postal addresses was held and whom had no email address, but not including those who emigrants, have permanently withdrawn from the study, died or been defined as 'permanently untraced'.
